title: Newtons second law - hanging block versus motor

content.question: Two identical blocks are placed on a table as shown in the figure. The block on the left is attached to another identical block hanging over the edge of the table. The block on the right is attached to a motor pulling downward with a constant tension equal to the weight of one block. The mass of the strings and friction between the blocks and table are negligible and the pulleys are ideal. How do the magnitudes of the acceleration of the blocks compare and why?

choices.label: The block on the right has a greater acceleration. The net force on the system with the motor is greater than the net force on the two-block system.
The block on the right has a greater acceleration. Each system has the same net force exerted on it, but the system on the right has less total mass.
Each block has the same acceleration. The tension in the string pulling on the blocks is the same in each case.
Each block has the same acceleration. The system of blocks on the left has twice the mass and also twice the weight compared to the block on the right.

content.answer: The block on the right has a greater acceleration. Each system has the same net force exerted on it, but the system on the right has less total mass.
